The reason that a black hole can't spin fast enough to expose its singularity is that, once it gets spinning fast enough, it becomes impossible to throw anything else into it that would add that last bit of angular momentum. Anything moving slowly enough to fall in will decrease the black hole's spin, and anything fast enough to push the black hole over the limit cannot be on a trajectory that would cause it to fall into the event horizon.

Why would the x-ray pulse only occur at the primary eclipse of the white dwarf? Because of the way light bends around massive gravitational bodies, we would expect to be able to see light coming from the white dwarf at all points in it's orbit. Additionally, it's usually safe to assume that white dwarfs are isotropic radiators, meaning that they emit the same in all directions. So it wouldn't intuitively make sense that we would only get a pulse from this white dwarf at primary eclipse. If it were enveloped by accretion disk material, wouldn't we see that emission throughout the orbit of the dwarf around the black hole?

It appears from our point of reference that the universe is expanding, but in fact it's accelerating towards the centre. Human perception vs. reality
Blackholes that grow big end up attracting stars and other matter around them forming galaxies. Since humans see the galaxies first, we incorrectly say that there is a blackhole in the center of every galaxy (instead of - there is a galaxy around a super-massive blackhole which would be the more correct representation). Is this really true ? Yes, because there can be a super-massive blackhole without a galaxy around it, but there cannot be a galaxy with no blackhole at the center, yet stuff revolves around it.

Why do we see stars !? A star is an omnidirectional emitter of coherent electromagnetic waves! In essence, we see a pillar of a ray of light! Everything is very simple! We see stars only because our Sun in our galaxy flies in sync with the rest of the stars! The distance between the stars is increasing, but it is so very - a slow process that lasts for millions of years. That is, an astronomer cannot observe the change in such long processes, since Earth time flies by with lightning speed! And so, now we know that distant stars are statically attached to one coordinate point in the sky, but why does the light of the stars travels so long distances, reaching our optic nerve? 4746

It's all about COHERENCE! The emitted light of the stars forms a kind of laser beam of light, in one of the radiation spectra such as X-rays this radiation is most effective. The rotation of the stars around their axis further enhances the coherence by pumping the beam. In fact, we see a column of a ray of light, but we see only that beam-column that flies in our direction, forming a peak - an energy point. In neighboring solar systems, people observe the phase radiation of the beam but several degrees to the side. The formed point in the sky confirms that the star is exactly in the place of its coordinates! if the Star could move relative to our Sun, then no coherent ray would be able to form.

To denote a motion one must first have a reference. By definition, a black hole mass is a static entity., because it has no time signature. Earth's time signature is based on the composite mass of our Solar System . Most black hole masses are defined as being hundreds or thousands of times more massive than our Sun. Ergo time would be at a virtual standstill. A black hole would not be rotating from a theoretical point of view, it could therefore not have a reference point from which to derive a rotational aspect or any relative motion aspect. This is theoretical evidence which disproves the very existence of a black hole mass.
You should also mention that we don't know what hypothetical black holes are because at the event horizon physics breaks down. Observing from a giant distance and creating the math is not knowing.

There's a lot of nonsense here. For one, this is science fiction and most of this is guesses since we still can't actually observe or test any of this. For two, spin makes no sense on a singularity. A point has no width, so even if it were spinning it wouldn't have an impact on anything around it (per relativity AND conservation of angular momentum), so the only thing spinning are things in orbit either stable or decaying. Black holes don't spin, not the way you want to conceptualize spinning, things falling into them do. That's of course assuming black holes actually exist as theorized, which is pure speculation.
Final equation for radius of a star: shouldn't it be T^4?
Nature seems to dictate spin in bodies such as planets, stars, planetary discs, black holes and galaxies in space. It seems to be a process of the way every celestial body is created.

Why would light be emitted at a certain spin speed? Doesn't the whole constant speed of light thing mean that the event horizon will remain the same regardless of the spin? I don't know how such an object would act, but I can think of ways in which you might not be able to tell:
-The accretion disk particles orbiting below the event horizon get slammed together during their orbits, causing them to form another black hole orbiting the black hole, and as such they don't give off radiation anymore. Therefore only the accretion disk which is above the event horizon is visible.
-General relativity below the event horizon messes up the radiation signal coming from the accretion disk, so that it mimics that of a black hole with spin below 1.

So, given that, are black holes with spin above 1 possible with current data?

What you say about the maximum spin of a black hole is not accurate as of the time you published this video. A blackhole spinning so fast that its event horizon disappears is called overspinning in the literature. There has been a string of papers in recent years strengthening the case that it is not possible to form an overspinning blackhole by accreting matter into a black hole that is below overspinning. Wald has written the latest paper I know of, and you will find in there the references to the other works: Wald, Robert M. (Aug. 2018). “Kerr–Newman black holes cannot be over-charged or over-spun”. In: International Journal of Modern Physics D 27.11, p. 1843003. The over-charged part of the title refers to what you alluded to in your video: black holes could a priori be charged. And it turns out that if their charge goes above some threshold, then the event horizon disappears as well. As you surely know, this is an example of the cosmic censorship hypothesis.

Do black holes even exist?

Of course, all this excitement would only be justified, if black holes really existed in this universe. So, do they?

In the last century strong evidence has mounted that certain binary stars with intense X-ray emissions are in fact stars collapsed into black holes.

Moreover, in the centres of galaxies we often find evidence for huge, dark concentrations of mass. These might be supermassive versions of black holes, possibly formed through the merger of many stars and gas clouds that have sunk into the centre of a galaxy.

The evidence is convincing, but circumstantial. At least gravitational waves have let us ‘hear’ the merger of black holes, but the signature of the event horizon is still elusive and so far, we have never actually ‘seen’ a black hole – they simply tend to be too small and too far and, in most cases, yes, black...

Just FYI, redshift can only be used to calculate distance at very large extra-galactic distances where the expansion of the universe accounts for most of the object's observed motion. At distances where we can resolve individual stars from stellar clusters (as opposed to resolving individual stellar discs), which we can only do within our galaxy and some members of the local galactic group, cosmological redshift can't be used because the Doppler shift primarily traces the stars' peculiar motions within their galaxies or of their host galaxies through their group or cluster. We can use stellar spectra to gauge a star's distance, but to do so we have to compare the spectra to stellar evolutionary models to distinguish dwarfs and giants of the same temperatures and estimate the star's intrinsic luminosity at that stage in its life. For isolated stars (not part of a multiple system or cluster but free-moving in the galactic potential), stellar evolutionary models are often the best distance-estimating tools available, and that's not saying a whole lot.

You say there are two ways supermassive black holes are created, swallowed stars or merging black holes. But in reality, both are proven to be impossible, due to the young age of the universe. There was simply not enough time, considering how rare these events are. This is a common misconception.

There is a third, most likely way. After the big bang, when there were no stars, just clouds of hydrogen and helium, these clouds collapsed into stars. But where the clouds were dense enough, they collapsed straight into black holes. The stars were created from the “leftover”.
There is an upper limit how many times a black hole can merge another black hole, or swallow a star. But there is no upper limit for how big the cloud can be which collapsed into a black hole. Therefore they can be supermassive.
That is the reason why we don’t see mid-size black holes. Either amcouple of sun’s size, or millions of sun’s size.

Black holes are truly fascinating. I've been giving them some thought recently too and come to my own understanding about how they work and what must be inside them, based on maths and facts that we already have. Since a black hole on a penrose diagram shows that the singularity is not a physical location but rather an eventual time - which makes sense since if you fell into a black hole you would inevitably meet the singularity at some point -  I believe it means that falling through the hole would mean falling down the 4th axis, or dimension, which must be time. This is reinforced by the fact that space and time are switched inside a black hole on a penrose diagram, and the closer you get to the event horizon, the more time warps, as we're reminded in the film 'Interstellar'. This means inside the black hole is a tunnel straight through time itself. As well, when we show mass curving space-time with the 3D universe being shown as a 2D grid that warps along he 3rd axis, I think the dip in space-time caused by the black hole does indeed still have a bottom, and that this means all the mass that formed the singularity is definitely still in there in some sort of physical form, most likely still with a 3D size, even. Just nerding out here, but the sentence "at frequencies that high, they must be orbitting very close in, probably near r_isco" doesn't seem right to me because I don't think you can say the star's orbit is near r_isco solely based on the frequency. So it made me think about how you would even know if it's anywhere near r_isco and this is what I've come up with.

Using the mass of the black hole and the frequency of the pulses you can calculate the radius of the orbit and the velocity of the star. Assuming there's a max velocity at which matter can have a stable orbit around a black hole, then the difference between the velocity of the star and the max velocity would give you an idea of how close it is to r_isco.

So I think without knowing the mass of the black hole it's impossible to know how close it is to r_isco. If you know of any other way, I'd be happy to hear about your thoughts ^^

Rotating black hole can be described by Kerr metric. According to Kerr metric, it's possible for a traveler from universe #1 to cross the horizons, avoid the singularity, and then cross the horizons again, and finally come out to universe #2. This theoretical path can be illustrated by Penrose diagram.

Since rotating back hole does exist, theoretically we do have a doorway into an alternative universe? Unfortunately, the solution is unstable and require the theory of quantum gravity which is incomplete.
